name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Il-punt li jmiss fuq l-aġenda huwa d-dibattitu dwar id-dikjarazzjoni tal-Kunsill u tal-Kummissjoni dwar Ir-relazzjonijiet futuri bejn l-UE u r-Renju Unit (2020/2922(RSP)). Nixtieq ninforma flower-onorevoli Membri li, għad-dibattiti kollha ta' din is-sessjoni parzjali, mhux se jkun hemm pro大edura "catch-the-eye" u mhux se jiġu a大ettati karti blu.  Barra minn hedge, huma previsti interventi mill-bogħod mill-Uffi大大ji ta' Kollegament tal-Parlament fl-Istati Membri.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice—President of the European Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I welcome this debate that gives us – Michel Barnier and myself – the opportunity to update you on both the ongoing negotiations on the possible future deal and the Withdrawal Agreement implementation. Let me start with a letter. As I previously mentioned to this House, Deal or No Deal, it was of utmost importance to ensure that the Withdrawal Agreement will be operational in time, as of 1 January 2021. This was a matter of trust and mutual respect of international law obligations. Yesterday, we held the fifth regular meeting of the EU—UK Joint Committee on the Withdrawal Agreement. This meeting marked an important milestone. It followed the bilateral agreement in principle that I had reached with the UK Co—Chair, Chancellor Michael Gove, last week and reported immediately back to the UK Coordination Group of the European Parliament. In the meantime, the Member States have managed to swiftly approve the relevant decisions, and today I am therefore pleased to confirm that we have officially endorsed the necessary formal decisions and practical solutions for the timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and that of its Protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland by the end of the transition period. In relation to the Protocol implementation, this means that we have delivered on our overarching objective: to protect the Good Friday Belfast Agreement, avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland, and thereby contribute to maintain peace, stability and prosperity on that island. This was only possible thanks to the dedication and solution—driven approach on both sides. This is also a testament to our shared commitment to the Good Friday Belfast Agreement. These solutions provide businesses and people in Northern Ireland with the necessary clarity and stability, while upholding the integrity of our single market.  As far as the EU is concerned, we have achieved our two main priorities. First, to obtain robust working arrangements for an EU presence in Northern Ireland so that our representatives can effectively carry out their tasks on the ground. In particular, I welcome that the UK has finally agreed to provide adequate equipment and facilities, as well as continuous real—time access to the relevant IT systems and databases both on the ground and remotely. Our EU representatives will thus be able to carry out their monitoring tasks on site at all places where goods and animals enter or exit Northern Ireland through ports or airports. This is key to ensure that the Protocol is implemented correctly by the UK authorities in Northern Ireland, thereby protecting the integrity of the EU single market. Second priority: to make sure that the UK Government not only continues to actively engage in the timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement, in the Joint Committee framework, but also commits to withdrawing all contentious parts of its Internal Market Bill and refraining from introducing any similar parts in its taxation bill. This it finally did last week, as part of our bilateral agreement in principle.  Given these reassurances, we were also able to find workable solutions for a number of areas. In detail, the Joint Committee adopted five decisions – four decisions on the Protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland: the evaluation decisions on the practical arrangements for the Union presence in Northern Ireland; a decision on goods not at risk of entering the EU single market; a decision on the exemption of agricultural and fish subsidies from state aid rules; and a decision to correct some technical errors and omissions in Annex II of the Protocol. And one decision on the extension of social security coordination to the European Economic Area and Switzerland, as of 1 January 2021.  The Joint Committee also took note of the list of 25 persons, including five chairpersons, to serve as arbitrators for the Dispute Settlement Mechanism under the Withdrawal Agreement. This decision will be adopted shortly.  In addition to these decisions, we have adopted a set of unilateral declarations to set out pragmatic and time—limited solutions where the UK was not fully ready for the end of the transition period, whilst ensuring credible pathways to full compliance in the forthcoming months. These solutions concern a number of areas: temporary border control posts specifically for checks on animals, plants and derived products; export declarations; the supply of medicines; the supply of chilled meat and other food products to the supermarkets; and clarification on the application of state aid rules under the terms of the Protocol.  I underline again that these temporary solutions are subject to strict conditions to ensure that all relevant stakeholders will be in a position to fully comply with the Protocol in the course of 2021. Last but not least, we also agreed to pursue our joint efforts in assuring that during the grace period until 30 June 2021 and beyond, the rights of our citizens and UK nationals are effectively protected. The Joint Committee thus endorsed and agreed to publish the Second Joint Report on the implementation of residents’ rights prepared by the respective specialised committee. This report provides an update on national residency schemes in the UK and in the European Union. It also outlines outreach and assistance measures to support EU citizens and UK nationals, including vulnerable groups, and to inform important stakeholders such as employers. Much remains to be done, but yesterday marked an important first and decisive step in living up to the commitments of the Withdrawal Agreement. Before passing the floor to our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, I want to underline that we will need to continue paying full attention to the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement in 2021. We will focus on how our mutually—agreed solutions will actually work on the ground. To this end, we also agreed yesterday that the Joint Committee will meet at least quarterly during the upcoming year.  I want to thank you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, for your support in this endeavour. I will of course continue to keep this House regularly abreast of, and closely associated with, all upcoming developments on the Withdrawal Agreement implementation front.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: head of the task force for relations with the United Kingdom. Madam President, hello to each and every one of you, in this very long and extraordinary negotiation which I have the honour of leading on behalf of the Commission and on your behalf for more than four years now, having succeeded together, with Parliament and the Council, in preparing a treaty of withdrawal from the European Union for the United Kingdom, as it wished.  It is this treaty that maroe 'eef-ovi' has just spoken of, which I would like to thank personally and before you for its tenacity and the efficiency with which he and our team have managed to organise, finally, all the last concrete and operational modalities, so that this treaty ratified last year by your Parliament and by the British Parliament is implemented, as we expected and as is normal and necessary for Ireland to be , the economy of the whole island and the protection of the internal market, and that it be operational in due course, in a few days. What we are talking about right now, in front of you, is a second negotiation. Beyond leaving the European Union, the question is whether the UK is leaving the single market and customs union with an agreement or no deal in 10 days. We are at a moment of truth. We have very little time left - a few hours - in this negotiation, if we want this agreement to come into force on 1 January. As our President Ursula von der Leyen told you two days ago, the possibility of an agreement is there , I think it is as a negotiator , but the road is very narrow. At a time when we have to make decisions, it will also be time for everyone to take responsibility. I will take mine, as I have done throughout my public engagement, in accordance with the mandate set for me by the 27 Member States of the European Union, which has been supported and confirmed by the vast majority of Parliament's political groups through your resolutions. Today I want to highlight three fundamental elements in this negotiation. It was the British who set the very short deadline to which we are now obliged. By refusing in June any form of extension of the transition that would have been possible, proposed to them and with which we agreed, they set the deadline of 31 December for this moment of truth. Should they come out, as we wish, with an agreement, or will they leave the single market and the customs union without agreement? It was the British who chose that deadline. The second point is that this is an extraordinary negotiation, conducted in nine months, as we have never seen in the past, on so many subjects that are at the heart of your resolutions and the mandate. Although we regret that the British did not have the will to go further, including through a foreign policy, defence and cooperation agreement, which we were prepared to negotiate, that is their choice. It takes two to negotiate and to reach an agreement. Nevertheless, what remains and what we have been working on for the last nine months is considerable, since it covers all subjects, or virtually all subjects, to establish new cooperation in other forms, in a new framework, after the departure of the British, in the areas where we have had, for 47 years, joint work and action within the framework of the Union. And that is why this partnership is unprecedented: both in the time required for negotiation — I recall that it took four or five years to negotiate a more modest agreement with Canada or with Japan — and by the magnitude of the issues we need to address. Finally, third point: in such an agreement - this is your mandate, this is your resolution - everything forms a coherent whole and there is no agreement on anything until there is agreement on everything. Nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. So it is not surprising that, in the last hours we are in, the very great difficulties of negotiation, the most difficult and the hardest points, as I have often said before the European Parliament's coordination group, which David McAllister leads, and yesterday again before the chairs of your groups, are also concentrated. Since the beginning of this negotiation, the British have set a fundamental requirement since the beginning of this negotiation, which is the raison d'être of Brexit, that they want to regain their full sovereignty. At the same time, they must respect the sovereignty of the Member States of the Union, which form a united whole across the European Union. And we have a fundamental requirement: this Union of 27 Member States, which operates democratically on a voluntary basis and under the control and impetus of your Parliament, is based on common values, common policies, an economic and social foundation that is the single market, much more than a free trade area, an ecosystem; and we call for the preservation of these values, these principles and this single market. We want open and ambitious trade and economic cooperation, but it must be fair and equitable, free and fair, fair and free. It must be based on what is called a level playing field - I prefer to say 'fair competition', 'fair competition', that is, fair competition rules and high standards, particularly in terms of social standards, the environment and climate. And if the sovereign United Kingdom wants to diverge in the future, that is its right, but it cannot be without consequences when it comes to having access to our markets without tariffs and quotas. The United Kingdom also wants to regain its sovereignty over fishing, to be able to control access to its waters. As I have said many times and I repeat before you, we accept it and we respect it. But if the United Kingdom wants, after a period of credible and sufficient adjustment, to be able to cut off access to its waters for European fishermen at any time, the European Union must also have a sovereign right to react or compensate, then adjusting the conditions of access to its market for all products, and in particular for fishing products. That is one of the major difficulties of negotiating this fisheries issue today, which is part of our overall economic partnership. Ladies and gentlemen, I personally believe that it would be neither fair nor acceptable for European fishermen to have only transitional rights in British waters that would one day evaporate, while the rest of the agreement, especially for British businesses, would remain stable. That would not be acceptable or fair. Those are the main points that separate us today. Of course, as you know, there are many other very important dimensions in the partnership that we are negotiating. I am thinking of a very broad economic cooperation through an ambitious, unique free trade agreement, such as we have never offered to any third country and which offers tariff-free and quota-free access with the rules I was talking about on the level playing field. I am thinking of connectivity in air and road transport and energy, or cooperation in social security. I am also thinking of our partnership in terms of internal security, the security of citizens, and God knows if everything that is happening around us geopolitically calls us to cooperate, to work for this security of citizens with the British. That is why we have already agreed in this negotiation on close cooperation in eight specific areas, on which many of you are working in their committees: Europol, Eurojust, Pmo, extradition, the exchange of information on criminal registers as well as the freezing and confiscation of assets. This cooperation for the security of citizens is based on two prerequisites that are now accepted: respect for fundamental rights, especially as enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, and the protection of personal data. That is where we are. The points that remain open in these crucial hours are fundamental points for the Union. We are asking for nothing more than a balance between rights and obligations and reciprocity in terms of access to our markets and waters. Nothing more, but nothing less. While it is clear that we want an agreement, it is also clear that we will not make that agreement at any cost. As I speak to you, very sincerely, and I have always spoken to you truthfully and sincerely, I cannot tell you what the outcome of this last stretch of negotiation will be. That is why we must be prepared for all scenarios, and that is why a series of texts with contingency measures are also put to your vote to prepare us for a possible no deal. On this point, I would like to thank you, and all the services and actors of the European Parliament, for your speed and your readiness to adopt these measures in a very rapid time, which will allow them to come into force, if there is no agreement, on 1 January next. We are also working together to operationalise the new Brexit adjustment reserve as soon as possible. I am leaving you very quickly, I apologise, since negotiations will resume. As the President of the Commission has asked me, we will resume negotiations this morning with David Frost and his team for one last attempt to reach an acceptable agreement, particularly on the issue of fisheries. We are not sure we will achieve this if everyone does not make a real and concrete effort to find a compromise. At this point I would like to thank you for your support, for your confidence which has never been denied since the beginning of our journey together. This confidence is based on a method that I proposed from day one and which was supported by President Juncker and then President Ursula von der Leyen, which is that of dialogue and permanent transparency. I know, including the chairman of the INTA committee, that there are additional requests. We are trying to answer that. There is also the general balance of this negotiation, which is not over. Our services, the task force team and I have tried to be as available as possible to bring you, throughout this long negotiation, the elements you needed. I think that is the reason for the trust that you have always shown me and which I want to thank you for.  I know, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the constraints that are yours for the democratic examination to which you are entitled and which is normal: I was a member of your House, I was a national parliamentarian for a very long time. This democratic issue is at the heart of this negotiation, which must be known, detailed and approved in the national parliaments and the European Parliament. Economic actors must have the means to appropriate it, because it is very important, and - if I may conclude - much more important than the relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union alone. It is the European project that is at issue. Throughout this negotiation, I have kept in mind three points of perspective and reference to try to put things in the long term.  The first point was peace in Ireland. It has been and remains a fundamental point for me, and that is why I thanked Maroo for the work that has been done to ensure the conditions of stability in Ireland. The second point is, of course, our Union. I have been mandated to defend the interests of this Union: the single market, consumers and citizens, businesses in all sectors. And then the third point of perspective: let us not forget, beyond Brexit, the United Kingdom is a great country that we respect, a partner country, neighbour, friend, ally with which we must have, in one way or another - if not today because we do not reach an agreement, it will be later - a strong bond and extremely ambitious cooperation. That is the whole point of this negotiation and the serious, very serious moment when we are in for its eventual conclusion. Thank you for your attention, thank you for your trust.

name: David McALLISTER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, as we have just heard, in less than two weeks the United Kingdom will leave the single market and the customs union and yet, until now, both sides have not been able to agree on our future partnership as of 1 January. The negotiations have indeed been intense and tough. They take place in an unprecedented environment and under extreme time pressure. The European Union has never negotiated an agreement with a third country of such scope, and only in nine months. Let me first of all thank Vice—President Maroš Šefčovič and our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, and their two teams, for their tireless work and the very good close and regular cooperation with the European Parliament, in particular during the recent weeks. The best solution for both sides would certainly be to reach a comprehensive agreement before the end of the year. This would provide clarity and this would provide predictability to citizens and businesses. Yesterday, the Conference of Presidents emphasised that we, as the European Parliament, stand ready to organise an extraordinary plenary session towards the end of December, in case an agreement is finalised by midnight this Sunday. We stand ready to debate the outcome of the negotiations intensively as soon as possible, and we stand ready to thoroughly scrutinise the final text. But, one thing has to be very clear: this would be a unique scenario and cannot and will not serve as a precedent for future agreements. There is a narrow path to an agreement, Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said on Wednesday here in the plenary. Indeed, I welcome the substantial progress made on many issues. However, as we heard this morning, differences remain to be bridged, in particular on fisheries, and we all know this will be very challenging. Since it is still not clear whether there will be an agreement in the end, we simply have to be prepared for all scenarios. The four targeted and time—limited contingency measures we will adopt today aim at limiting some of the most severe consequences in areas where no fall—back solutions exist.  Disruption will happen with or without an agreement. This is the natural consequence of the British decision to leave the European Union and to no longer participate in our single market and customs union. I remain convinced that it is in our mutual interest to agree on a sustainable, a trustful and a balanced partnership with the United Kingdom, which is one of our closest partners and an ally.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, after four years of agonizing in our relations with the United Kingdom, today we would have wanted to discuss and adopt a treaty that will enable us to build the best relationship for citizens and businesses on both sides of the English Channel.  Unfortunately, populist rhetoric, which has been catching the British right for a decade, prevents it until now. We must not hide that the formalization of contingency measures makes us feel the gravity of the moment. But citizenship can be quiet. Thanks to contingency plans we will be able to minimize the impending chaos that would occur in the event of a breakdown in air, rail and road transport, as well as in the fishing sector. Contingency plans should also help us to send London a clear warning: the Commission, the 27 Member States and this Parliament will maintain our cohesion to the end.  We are aware that the absence of an agreement in the current circumstances of the pandemic would be very negative for both economies. But we also know that the UK would suffer even more if an agreement is not reached. Let us not give in at a time when Mr. Johnson is increasingly alone. The cost of an uncavoiced Brexit would be another major blow to the British economy after the pandemic. Major British companies are pressuring him for a deal, and his anti-European godfather, Donald Trump, will soon be history.  Of course we should keep looking for a deal before a bad breakup. And we can only continue to thank the commendable commitment of the negotiating team, led by Mr Barnier, to reach the best agreement. But to achieve this, Parliament's voice must also be heard. The provisional application of the agreement before Parliament has expressed its consent is not acceptable. This would jeopardize the rigorous and democratic examination that European citizens deserve.  That is why, Mr Barnier, we hope that the Commission will forward the provisional text of the agreement to us as soon as possible. We need time. This is how we leaders have agreed in a consensual manner. We will only discuss the outcome of the negotiations before the end of the year if an agreement is reached before midnight on This Sunday 20 December. The spirit of cooperation between the Commission and Parliament must also guide the Member States. Let us not allow London's strategy to let the fisheries agreement pass through at the end of the negotiation. A fair fisheries agreement would guarantee both the right of European fishermen to fish in British waters and UK fisheries exports in the European Union.  Our red line must remain the defence of the single market. Under no circumstances can we allow the UK free access to the single market if the Johnson Government does not undertake to meet the same regulatory standards for Europe. If the British government abandons its nationalist maximalism and returns to pragmatism, there is still time.  Negotiating a treaty does not imply the loss of sovereignty. And the United Kingdom and the European Union negotiate as sovereign parties on an equal footing, because we want to ensure the prosperity of peoples united by historical ties that will always accompany us.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, dear Michel, John le Carré has just left us. Everyone knows what they thought of Brexit. To say the least, he was not listened to. But today, there is no point in ruminating on the past. The time has come to build the future of relations between the United Kingdom and our Union and this hour has come. We can build a relationship where our sovereignty is respected and our interests are preserved.  We face the same challenges. Climate change, COVID, the economic crisis, terrorism, an unstable and unpredictable world, repeated attacks on our democracies are threats in London and Paris as well as in Berlin or Brussels. These threats ignore borders and no country can face them alone.  In the past, the adventure of splendid isolation has turned short and given way to cordial understanding. This is a new cordial agreement that the European Union is proposing to the United Kingdom.  It goes through an agreement like never before Europe has signed with any country, an unprecedented agreement for an unparalleled partner. An agreement in which we would choose sovereignly, on both sides, to allow access to our markets and access to our waters. An agreement in which we would sovereignly choose to continue to be ambitious in terms of the environment, the protection of our workers, the protection of our data. An agreement that would allow us to continue the exchanges between our polices, our justices, our researchers, our students. An agreement where we would choose to focus on the reality of what brings us closer rather than the illusion of what divides us. However, a few days before the end of the year, this agreement has not yet been concluded and we are now voting on measures in case the negotiations fail. We do not want these negotiations to fail, but it is our duty to be prepared for all scenarios. Above all, it is our common duty to freely choose to walk side by side rather than turn our backs.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Qabel ma nkomplu bid-dibattiti, niftaħ l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni tal-lum. Se nivvotaw dwar il-fajls kif indikati fl-aġenda. Is-sessjoni ta' votazzjoni se tkun miftuħa mid-09.30 sal-10.45. Il-votazzjonijiet se jsiru bl-istess metodu użat fis-sessjonijiet ta' votazzjoni preeddient. Il-votazzjonijiet kollha se jsiru b'sejħa tal-ismijiet. Niddikjara miftuħa l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni. Għandkom sal-10.45 biex tivvotaw. Ir-riżultati tal-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni se jitħabbru fis-13.00.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Issa nkomplu d-dibattitu tagsna dwar id-dikjarazzjoni tal-Kunsill u tal-Kummissjoni dwar Ir-relazzjonijiet futuri bejn l-UE u r-Renju Unit (2020/2922(RSP).

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, whether or not the final negotiations lead to an agreement or a provisional agreement, which would once again relegate our Parliament to a role as a chamber for recording decisions taken elsewhere, the time is obviously on the balance sheet, four and a half years after the sovereign choice of the British people.  The original sin here in Brussels was to criticise and despise the decision of the British people, who had nevertheless voted by referendum by an absolute majority. In the ideological approach of European integration, everything has been planned to expand, expand ever more and unreasonably; nothing has been planned to allow a country to leave the European Union in good conditions. Then you negotiated a deal with Theresa May whose terms - and you knew this perfectly well - were unacceptable to the House of Commons, unacceptable to the British people. And of course, by saying that this text was frozen, unspeakable from any modification, you were hoping to iron the dishes and make sure that the British would come back on their choice. Here in Brussels, many were drawing up plans to trample on democracy and cancel the 2016 vote outright. This manoeuvre was a bit pathetic for the European institutions, as Boris Johnson, as soon as he won the election, evacuated the first text. New negotiations have begun. What a waste of time!  Finally, what is likely to cost us dearly in the coming days has been the refusal to deal upstream with the most sensitive and contentious issues. The rules of fair competition, for example: the United Kingdom is being asked to respect European standards, including the decisions of the Court of Justice, even though this is precisely one of the reasons, one of the reasons why they left the European Union. The Union today negotiates free trade agreements, trade agreements, with the whole world. It gives tax, financial and economic benefits to some of the most critical countries, such as Pakistan or Turkey. And we would not achieve a reasonable and balanced trade agreement with the great ally, friend and neighbour that is the United Kingdom?  Another problem, of course: fishing. Fishing is a fundamental point. Let us hope that the interests of the Netherlands, Denmark and France are not sacrificed because Berlin does not see it as a fundamental interest and issue.  Finally, of course, we have an interest in having a quality agreement with the United Kingdom. Let us not play the prophets of doom. We were predicted the seven plagues of Egypt if Brexit were voted on, a shower of calamities if Boris Johnson became Prime Minister; none of this has happened. Let us simply remember that democracy was founded in Europe by our civilization. The United Kingdom decided to leave because Brussels often forgot about democracy.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the path to a possible agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom, albeit narrow, remains open. I have no doubt that our negotiating teams, led by Michel Barnier, are committed to preserving the vital interests of the Union, starting with the integrity of its internal market. And, who knows, perhaps a trade agreement will emerge from this negotiation which, in contrast to those that the Union has passed so far, commits a healthy emulation towards ever-higher social, environmental and other standards, rather than a perpetual race to the least. Ladies and gentlemen, let me tell you that I am outraged by the position taken yesterday by the group presidents of our Parliament who did not accept, but spontaneously proposed on their own, that we ratify a possible agreement in a few days, after what can only be a mock examination. I have been an MEP for more than eleven years and I have heard many colleagues regularly complaining about the lack of respect that parliament would be subjected to from the Commission and the Council. These are sometimes justified complaints, but gaining the respect of others starts with self-respect; and yesterday's offer ridicules Parliament. Indeed, how can we believe that in a few days we can sift through a treaty of unprecedented volume and political importance for the Union, which we have not yet seen the first paragraph of? Whatever confidence we may have in our negotiators and the political likelihood of ratification, what is at stake here is respect for the procedures, responsibilities and roles of counter-powers, so-called checks and balances, crucial elements of a democratic regime. By proposing expeditious ratification, a majority of this Parliament sets a deleterious precedent. It sends the signal that, even if our Parliament rolls the mechanics, it will always ratify the treaties proposed to it, even at the last moment. However, it is precisely the implicit pressure created by the ratification process by the legislative body that keeps the executive - here, the Commission - under democratic control. Otherwise, the officials who de facto write the treaties operate in freewheeling. What is the point of giving them a negotiating mandate if we are not in a position to verify, in the end, the compliance of the final texts with that mandate? The weakening of democratic control inevitably leads to abuses of power. Like you, I do not like the principle of a provisional application of the Treaty, but this one, contrary to what some say, preserves the prerogatives of Parliament, since it is sufficient for Parliament to refuse ratification for it to end. On the other hand, it is not the only way to give Parliament time for a review. There is nothing, legally, to prevent two freely consenting parties from extending the status quo of their relations by a month or two. Colleagues, across the Union, too many parliaments are increasingly being treated by their governments as mere registration chambers. I can only deplore the fact that a majority of the European Parliament, on its own initiative, is joining this grim development. This is all the more ridiculous since we have just fought together a fierce and successful battle over the European budget and on the beginning of the conditionality of European subsidies to respect for the rule of law. I'm telling you, pull yourself together.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we have come a long way, but now is the time to close the deal. History will be harsh on both the European Union and the United Kingdom if we fail on the ultimate stretch.  My group, the ECR, wants a deal. We have always been very close to the British, in particular the Conservative Party. British Conservatives were co—founders of our group. They offered us professionalism, pragmatism and a sense of humour. In the Conservative Party an understatement is an expression of survival, since your opponent within is never far away – basically behind you! However, that party also produced historic leaders like Winston Churchill and Margaret Thatcher with the power of strong personalities.  Since the British have left, the European Parliament has become more boring, if I may say, and without Nigel Farage over there in the corner, rather quiet, like a provincial assembly. But Mr Farage has found other topics to play the naughty boy of Britain. Without the British, the right to dissent seems to disappear from this Parliament, unfortunately. There is mounting pressure for la pensée unique. Open debate and conflicting arguments, however, are ways to test ideas against reality. Too many narratives in this Chamber remain in a void of self—complacency, missing the much—needed reality check. Without the British, the European Parliament tends to become a kind of religious congregation mainly convinced of itself.  We have to look for ways to keep these qualities the British have brought to this Parliament in which, ironically, English remains the main language of communication without interpretation.  The Brexit negotiations have also shown cultural differences. The French always have une logique and a big design; the British rather proceed case by case, picking the cases that serve them best, as Mr Barnier may have noticed.  I thank Mr Barnier, Mr Šefčovič and Mr Frost, including their teams, for all the efforts to find common ground from different positions. Madam President, we have to close the deal, but Parliament should not resort to grandstanding. Regarding a possible agreement it’s simply ‘yes’ or ‘no’. Political groups should work on a resolution for debate here in Brussels. The vote could be carried out remotely – a useful practicality we have mastered in this eventful year. Let us establish an EP—UK parliamentary delegation to remain in dialogue and to meet old friends in a new era.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I want to start with the better news. Firstly, today we are clearing the way for emergency aid and measures in the event of a no deal – that is a good signal to workers and their businesses in the European Union, which is a good signal to the European fishing industry.  However, I would also like to suggest here, Commissioner, that, in the event of more serious economic upheavals, we are considering entrusting the European Investment Bank with the task of setting up a fund to support small and medium-sized enterprises in particular in the event of these serious consequences for these companies. Secondly, I welcome the progress made in the negotiations on the implementation and implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and the Irish Protocol, to which the Commissioner referred. As a reminder to all of us, full implementation is not only a prerequisite for securing peace in Northern Ireland; it is also a prerequisite for this Parliament to be able to approve a treaty at all. According to Michel Barnier, we are now at a crossroads in the negotiations, and if an agreement is reached in the coming hours, it will be up to me and my group to decide how we should proceed to such an agreement, whether we agree or– on the basis of the content – veto it. And the Commission has started by announcing that this agreement is the first agreement of a new generation of trade agreements, namely a Fairtrade agreement. And we will judge the Commission precisely because we, as leftists in the European Parliament, have been fighting for a new generation – for other trade agreements – for many years, namely agreements that provide a strong response in the social and labour areas, the environment, human rights issues and consumer protection – not only for the EU, but also for trading partners. The problem is that we no longer have time to examine a deal in a truly parliamentary-parliamentary way. Nor can we organise a real democratic debate with each other or with the European public – but that is precisely our job as MEPs! That is precisely what our work is in the interests of Europeans, and it is totally unacceptable that we have not yet had at least access to the draft texts. Mr Barnier, I hope that the negotiations will be concluded in the coming hours, partly because that would perhaps give us a little more time to read the texts in depth. And to the British Government, I would like to say: move, but pronto!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 31 December is approaching, the final date by which, according to the withdrawal agreement signed last January, the other agreement on future trade relations between the United Kingdom and the European Union should be closed. This period, which is unfortunately characterised by a pandemic crisis, should have prompted the British Government to accept an extension of the negotiations, which would have been wise and timely. However, this situation cannot and must not be to the detriment of the fundamental principles that have been clearly defined in the Withdrawal Agreement.  In particular, we cannot tolerate in any way backward steps or derogations on the level playing field, which is fundamental for equal access to the single market. The assumption that, once the agreement has been concluded, the United Kingdom may lower its standards, by unfair competition to our companies, which are already in difficulty with the crisis, perhaps by inflating state subsidies or by resorting to social dumping, is totally unacceptable and we must reject it with all our might.  Yes, we want to work until the last second to get a good deal, but that will not happen at any cost, nor especially at any price.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Madam President, as we go down to the wire today, we meet again still none the wiser as to the outcome of the negotiations on the future partnership. Let me assure you, everybody is fed up of waiting for Godot! But if this Parliament has shown flexibility it is because, Michel Barnier, the UK Task Force and Maroš Šefčovič have gone above and beyond to keep Parliament and the Council abreast at every twist and every turn of these negotiations.  It is not because our negotiators refused to extend the transition period, Mr Lamberts. It is because the UK is running down the clock. It is because we have the historic responsibility to shield people and businesses as well as possible from the historic lack of responsibility the UK Government is showing. With today’s contingency votes, we show that we are not putting all our eggs in the same Brexit basket. We must be prepared for every eventuality, protecting those who would fall deepest off the famous cliff—edge that seems inevitable without a deal this weekend.  A No Deal Brexit would be a serious failure of statecraft and hit citizens and businesses in the most brutal manner. Therefore, I call one last time on Prime Minister Johnson: embrace this weekend’s ultimate chance to give priority to citizens over political cynicism. We owe this to our current and future negotiations. Our hand remains extended.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, we are running out of time. Negotiations are progressing, divergences remain, and in the meantime the transition period is about to end. Citizens are worried, businesses are nervous with all this uncertainty, and we have to ask ourselves, why are we in this terrible situation? For two reasons really. The first one is that Prime Minister Boris Johnson always refused even to consider an extension of the transition period. He knew that to conclude these difficult negotiations in such a short period of time would be unprecedented. He knew that back in June, when an assessment was made, progress was far from sufficient. He also knew the dramatic consequences of COVID—19 on our negotiations and the fact that we are facing the worst recession since World War II. But even so, he always refused to consider an extension of the transition period.  The second reason why we are where we are: the UK Government is taking endless time to realise that some illusions of Brexit simply cannot be delivered. Yes, the UK is a sovereign country, entitled to take back control of laws, borders and waters. Nobody in the EU is denying that, but we have to recall that we are just having this conversation because the UK – despite being out of the EU, the single market and the customs union – wants to maintain access to the European market with zero tariffs and zero quotas. The EU answers ‘okay we are ready to go that far if you ensure fair competition’. So this is no punishment. This is not about regulatory freedom. This is a deal. A fair deal.  Michel Barnier, Maroš Šefčovič, we thank you, we support you, and we are sure that, as soon as the British Government understands reality, the negotiations will reach a positive outcome. That reality in this case is very simple: an ambitious agreement can only be reached if fair competition is ensured, if a common level playing field, in a credible manner, is ensured for the future relationship. (Applause)

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Madam President! Now we are in the absolute final stages of an utterly tragic process. It is the British themselves who want to leave the EU, and it is the British themselves who have set the end date to be the end of this year - not the EU!  This chaotic process is surely a long example of how one bad decision can bring many bad decisions. Once one mistake has been made, yes, it is obvious that more people are following along, and it can be difficult to understand how internal English Conservative party politics has now become a European issue.  But now we are there, unfortunately, and to the detriment of ordinary people in fishing, in agriculture, in industry, who risk losing their jobs because of Brexit. The EU has gone a long way. Our skilled negotiator Michel Barnier deserves a price for his patience. But at the end of the day, it must be up to our good English friends to decide for themselves whether they will continue to trade with us, because we cannot and must not compromise the EU's single market. It is not reasonable for British companies to have both access to the single market and at the same time be able to outperform European or Danish companies on unequal conditions of competition.  We can hope and certainly work for a sensible agreement here at the very last minute, but it must be fair and it must be fair for both parties.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Vice-President Šefčovič and negotiator Barnier, who has now had to leave the chamber.  In my previous experiences I have learned many things. My father had a small business and I learned that the client was always right, that those who went to him to buy things should not be slapped in the face. This is what some arson workers in this House would like and have wasted many months on hard and complex negotiations, and as a member of the Committee on International Trade, I know how complex trade negotiations are.  Today we are on 18 December and we must above all thank the fact that Britain has failed to conclude a trade agreement with the United States. It would probably have replaced some of the goods that normally come from our single market to them. Some people have said that there has been little transparency. Some political groups are totally excluded from the flow of information. This is normal, I know, it also happens for other trade negotiations, but it is one of the problems on which, together with our friends in the Committee on International Trade, you know very well, we have discussed and it is a problem that applies today and will also apply for the future.  I do not agree with those who complain about the level of standards in Britain because, if it was a country that was with us until the other day, the European Parliament itself is giving the go-ahead to trade agreements with Asian companies that do not respect environmental standards, workers' rights; we have not suspended Turkey from the customs union with the European Union, I mean, it would be hypocritical, to say the least, to raise these issues at this stage. So let's turn the page, think of European businesses and workers and try to understand the lessons that have come from Brexit.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: – Madam President, we are at the eleventh hour of the negotiations. Significant progress has been made on the Northern Ireland Protocol, on citizens’ rights and on the level playing field. Ensuring peace and a diplomatic link with Northern Ireland now seems possible. Ensuring there are standards – high, democratic, environmental, social standards – in our trading and cooperation with the UK is still a priority. But time is ticking and we no longer have the possibility for scrutiny before 31 December, so we cannot fulfil our duty as Members of this Parliament.  Running down the clock should not be an effective negotiation tactic. We are seriously endangering our future relationship with the UK if we accept a last—minute deal and if we submit ourselves to this shameful UK government’s strategy of delaying talks since one year ago. There cannot be blind trust. We are here to protect the rights of citizens, both in the EU and the UK. Let’s take the example of data protection. We already know that Facebook is planning to shift the oversight of data belonging to British users from Ireland to the USA. Once again, this UK government has a very problematic record on data protection aspects. So we cannot sign an agreement with them, an adequacy agreement, with no further scrutiny. We need at least a technical extension, a six—week—minimum scrutiny period, written into any deal that would be made.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the Vice-President for getting the withdrawal agreement back on track and for making it operational. I would also like to thank Mr Barnier and his negotiating team - he has had to leave us for understandable reasons - for that months-long commitment and tough exhausting negotiations that require a great deal of human being. He has done so with great tenacity, with lucidity, with the necessary pragmatism and with flexibility. My question is that everything would be done to reach an agreement in those last days, last hours. The consequences, ladies and gentlemen, of a no deal are terrible for the European Union. In total, we lose 1.2 million jobs. All this is on top of the coronary disaster. The UK is losing more than half a million jobs. In my small Flanders we lose 2.6% of our GDP and 30 000 jobs.  I would therefore ask the Commission to speed up the Brexit fund for the regions most affected, for the sectors most affected. I would also ask for some compensation for the adverse consequences of Brexit and to speed up new trade deals, which we will absolutely need. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that it should be possible to reach an agreement with pragmatism, with flexibility, to strike a balance between the sovereignty of the British and the integrity of our internal market, which they must respect. There are mechanisms for state aid, for competition rules, for maintaining our standards, for governance. The same for fisheries, where we recognise sovereignty, but where we must have sufficient access, have sufficient quotas and, above all, legal certainty for our fishermen.  I agree with Mr Barnier's words that we need to think about the future, that we should go for a post-Brexit partnership not only on defence and security, but also on research and development, on Erasmus+, on university cooperation and cooperation in and around the North Sea, for the blue economy: the 21st century will be the century of the oceans. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that we must also work on interparliamentary cooperation with the British once Brexit is complete. We are also going to have to learn lessons from Brexit. This must not be repeated, this misery. Article 50 will have to be revised. I hope it will never be applied again. But whoever leaves has to come up with a proposal, with a blueprint. We will also have to provide more resistance to populism ourselves, and the EU will have to come up with achievements on the internal market, on jobs and prosperity, on trade treaties and on a conclusive migration policy.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you to Vice-President Eefsovic and, quite explicitly, michel Barnier for not leaving the negotiating table – despite our stinging in the British fog, whether the negotiations are successfully concluded or still going on – and stoically, with patience and perhaps tactical skill, he is seeking a treaty that can at least provide a solid and resilient basis for a future partnership relationship – with equal duties and rights. But: what does the Sovereign expect in the 27 EU Member States, what do the citizens actually expect from us, the co-legislator, in view of the situation that has now arisen? That we simply tick off a thousand-page agreement with many details and give the green light to its entry into force – will the right thing have already been negotiated? The expectations of fishermen and those working in agriculture, those working in industry and services, pensioners, students and so many others are high.  What is the final compromise? Are the standards of equal conditions of competition established by the European Parliament still effective in the fine print? Are there any enforcement tools in place? This is particularly true with regard to employment standards, social and environmental rights and governance. The ETUC was quite clear, as were the environmental associations or farmers' associations.  The deal must be historic, just as we have made maintaining peace in Northern Ireland with the UK and the EU in recent years, the acquired rights of citizens and a constructive shaping of economic cooperation with a view to shaping the future the benchmark of the European Parliament's position in the Brexit process.  Let us be honest: the loss of trust and mistrust in politics that has occurred is already enormous among citizens – here and on the island – beyond the concrete agreements and objectives of trade policy. Let us not continue to damage democracy! Let us take the necessary time to check if there is something to examine.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Madam President, I could start a sob story about my grandson, who I love dearly and who lives in the UK, but I won’t. Let’s take the emotions out of the Brexit story and be rational. The Brits are leaving the EU but they’re not leaving Europe. They will forever be our neighbours and, luckily, politicians can’t change that. Wealthy neighbours are to be preferred over poor ones.  A Brexit deal is in the making; only two issues remain. The Brits want to rule their own waves – that’s understandable – and then there is the issue of the level playing field and arbitrage. It is the duty of politicians to solve problems, instead of making them. Let’s be creative and think about the least bad constructions: licences of fishery rights for European fishermen, financial compensation schemes or a Brexit fund. Use your imagination. Make a deal – not an ambitious deal, but the best deal possible. Jobs are at stake here. Mr Barnier and all EU leaders, EU citizens are counting on you.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, I come up to this rostrum with many uncertainties and with some certainty. We don't know if it could or couldn't have been. We do not know whether, after centuries fishing in UK waters, our boats will stop fishing there on the unexplained whim of an irresponsible politician.  Because yes, that is what Brexit was: irresponsibility, aggravated by the inability to reach a reasonable exit agreement so far, mainly on fishing. And if this is the case, and we do not reach an agreement, the European fleet will have to look for other waters to continue fishing. And the British will have to look for other markets, while the whole world will wonder why it is nonsense. The position of the European Parliament and the Council is clear. It has not changed and should not change at this crucial moment in the negotiations. We have sought until exhaustion a sensible agreement on fisheries. I know, and I appreciate the enormous efforts made by our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier. But so far it has not been possible, despite the constructive attitude of the European Union. But that doesn't mean we threw in the towel. Quite the opposite. European fishermen know a lot about sailing despite the difficulties and will continue to do so.  The common fisheries policy is a compromise between the Member States of the European Union, including the United Kingdom, because together with them we have built this system, and it would not be fair or acceptable for European fishermen to have no rights.  It's not time to settle for an un agreed exit. It's not even time to look for responsibilities, either. It is time to keep working until the last minute, although it is true that the last minute is already too close for these waters to see European Union-flagged boats again fishing and our markets open up to the UK, because deep down, the British and the whole world, beyond radical positions, know that it is the best and they want it that way.  In this last effort, Europe needs to remain more united than ever. Our fishermen and Europe, including the UK, deserve it.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, one year ago, we offered the United Kingdom something we had never offered any third country: the most comprehensive partnership that the EU has ever concluded. We stand by our offer. The European Parliament has consistently been extremely flexible, patient and constructive throughout the negotiations. We will continue to do everything within our power to avoid a no-deal Brexit, because we are aware of the crucial importance of such an agreement for our citizens and our businesses. But we also remain realistic. There are only 13 days left until the end of the transition period. A no-deal has never been closer, and our citizens and businesses deserve clarity and predictability. That is why, today, we are ensuring that planes can keep flying, trucks can keep running and fishermen can keep fishing after 31 December. These contingency measures are of course no substitute for a deal, but they will alleviate, if necessary, the otherwise unavoidable disruption for both EU and UK citizens. Because, in spite of Michel Barnier’s tireless work and dedication, the UK Government has still not found the courage to find an agreement. Prime Minister Johnson has yet to acknowledge that every agreement is a compromise and that there is no such thing as having all the benefits of EU membership if you decided to leave. While trade deals are normally about convergence, this agreement deals with future divergence. When sovereign States decide to strike a deal, it is normally not used as a badge to prove their sovereignty. And at a time when all European nations are in the midst of an economic recession due to a pandemic, it would only be sensible to avoid another blow to our businesses and citizens.  The European Parliament has been patient, but democracy cannot and will not bend to the UK’s lack of responsibility. It is Boris Johnson who refused to even consider an offer for the transition period. Our right to post-democratic scrutiny of any agreement will not be compromised, and there will be no provisional application without parliamentary consent.  It is my sincere hope that a deal will be reached – a good and a fair deal for the citizens on both sides of the Channel. And it will have been worth it, every single second of it, because as one of the greatest from the UK would say about these negotiations, ‘All’s well that ends well’.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Madam President, there are less than two weeks left until 1 January and there is still no certainty that we can agree to a deal. It would be a grave understatement to say that this situation is very unpredictable for our citizens and companies. The only certainty that they have now is that the situation will change; with or without a deal, there will be different rules and different procedures. But let’s try to keep the hurt of Brexit to a minimum. The EU and the UK will both benefit from a fair deal that ensures a level playing field and fair competition and that is future-proof. I hope the negotiators are still aiming for that and that they will conclude a deal as soon as possible, so we can finally say, ‘You have done your job, now let us do ours’, so the European and UK people can finally get back to their jobs and their lives. Let’s put our differences aside and focus on what unites us, because a good deal is in everyone’s interest and should form the basis for our future relationship based on shared values and appreciation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. To understand today's debate on deal or no deal, we also need to look back to 2016, when a majority of the British people said they no longer want to be part of the European Union. And it would have been the right task for the European family of nations to oppose this decision with respect and to counter it with respect to the majority of Britons. That has been missed. From the very first second, a decision that, in the eyes of many here, could not be seen, which was not allowed to be, was not met with friendship, but disapproved of it, repeatedly imposed punitive sanctions, and the worst thing for me was that chief negotiators of the European Union met the British here with inconveniences that do not belong to a European family of nations. I would remind you, for example, of The President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Tusk, who would have preferred the Brexiteers to go to hell. I would remind you of the parliamentary negotiator Verhofstadt, who compared the people who pushed Brexit with unwelcome people from the French Revolution. That is the wrong way to go, ladies and gentlemen. But the decision has been made as to how it was made. And behold, the British on their way out of the European Union are suddenly mobile, can make decisions all at once. Just two examples: in the Corona crisis, for example, which affects us all, the situation is that the British have been vaccinating people who want vaccination for two weeks now, and the European Union has not yet started here. Or another example, which is also very important to me: in the area of this agonising animal transport, the British are now putting in place a solution to finally put an end to these agonising transports, and the European Union is still unable to create proper conditions here. Ladies and gentlemen, I appeal to you: use the objectives of these negotiations to treat the British with friendship and respect. For perhaps one day, when this European Union is reformed and the British want to return, they should remember that the start of the negotiations ended with friendship and respect for them, and not with disapproval and tones that should not be used in the political debate.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Madam President, ask not, as the line goes, for whom the bell tolls. As the clock ticks down to 31 December we look forward to ringing in a New Year that will surely be an improvement on the one we’ve been through. The bells of the New Year will herald hope, but so too will they toll for a bleaker tale, as 31 December marks the end of an era and Brexit becomes a harsh reality. This week we are seeing contingency measures being put in place in preparation for a no-deal Brexit on issues including transport and fisheries. The measures are a bare, but a crucial, minimum in terms of protecting livelihoods and links with our EU partners. But they do not provide any clarity around protection of our waters or our coastal communities and fishers – the men and the women who bring food to our tables. Scouts in Ireland say: ‘Bí Ullamh’ – be prepared. We can but try. Ask not for whom the bell tolls, I repeat. Brexit will impact on all our lives. And the Brexit bell will toll for each and every one of us.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The United Kingdom has left the European community but has not left Europe. The UK remains our neighbour, ally and economic partner. The establishment of a new relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom is important not only because of the need for ongoing negotiations, but above all because of the need to maintain Western unity at a time of growing geopolitical challenges.  The future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom must take into account very strong economic links, common values and convergence of objectives in many areas. At the same time, they must ensure an appropriate balance of rights and obligations and take into account the political sensitivities of each party. Strong economic links mean greater ambition, not only to access each other's markets, but also to ensure a level playing field.  The future agreement should ensure that new border control procedures are minimised while maintaining high security standards. This is particularly true for agri-food commodities, which are particularly sensitive to border delays and regulatory issues. We need new solutions in the area of transport: the vast majority of the European Union and UK road transport is served by EU carriers. The agreement should provide for very ambitious solutions on this issue, unprecedented in EU trade agreements. I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in addition to the economic dimension, cooperation in the field of internal security and justice must also be an important pillar of cooperation. Britain has left the European Union, but common threats remain. The exchange of data to combat crime, judicial cooperation in criminal matters, simplified extradition procedures or, finally, cooperation within Europol should all include a new partnership. Threats such as fanatical Islamic terrorism, human trafficking, drugs, arms trafficking remain real. Brexit does not change anything here, and our cooperation to ensure the safety of our citizens remains our priority at all times. There is another foundation connecting the United Kingdom and the Community of the European Union. This foundation is the values induced from Greek philosophy, Roman law, the Old testament and the New Testament. One of these pillars is Christianity. As christmas time approaches, memories of the birth of Jesus Christ, all the best for all, including those living in The United Kingdom today, including more than 700,000 of my compatriots, Poles. Happy holidays!

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, there’s no doubt about it that break-ups can often be ugly and hostile. This one has certainly been no exception, and I for one am heartily glad that it’s coming to an end, because for four years we’ve been fed a diet in Ireland that this is the end of the world as we know it. But you know what? It isn’t, because business is business and a way will be found. It may be the case that some of the new arrangements are disruptive in the short-term, but new arrangements will be found. I just think it’s an awful pity that a lot of this debate was marred by so much sneering and triumphalism. From, on the one hand, claiming aren’t those Brits awful eejits that didn’t even know what they were voting for, to being outraged that the Royal Navy might police British waters. Well, why wouldn’t they, when Spanish, French and Portuguese trawlers are already destroying the seabeds and interfering with our fisheries rights in Ireland? So, the idea that the EU was driven by high values while the Brits were just out for themselves is utter nonsense. Both sides are looking out for themselves. But we should remember here today that 17 million European citizens voted to leave the European Union. There are tens of millions more who are being let down. The real division isn’t between the EU and the UK; it’s between the haves and the have-nots. We need to start dealing with that or there’ll be a lot more Brexit to come.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, the outcome is still uncertain, but whatever the outcome, let me thank the efforts of the negotiation teams.  The difficulty to get this agreement should be a lesson for us in the future. If the EU is convinced of our potential and strength, we should have no fear in becoming more open and flexible, both to enter and to leave the EU. The EU needs a clarity act - a clarity act to lay the ground for an orderly exit of any Member State with a mandate to leave and it should also establish clear paths into the EU - a path that we hope our fellow Scottish friends will follow soon.  The basis, also, for the internal enlargement of the Union should also be fixed - with no taboos. This is the path that we, as Catalans, wish to follow soon.  Political unions strictly based on transparent and democratic principles last longer than those that are not. The more free and democratic the rules are, the more united we will remain.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As donald tusk, the previous President of the European Council, said, the choice we faced was either a hard Brexit or no Brexit. And it came out on his. Today we are facing either a hard Brexit or an ultra-hard Brexit. Millions of Europeans and Britons and businesses still do not know what the shape of this agreement will be and whether there will be an agreement at all on 1 January. You will have to fill out millions of forms so that everything remains more or less the old way. That is why I still do not understand what the good is going to be as a result of Brexit.  I would like to thank and congratulate the European Commission, including our chief negotiator, who professionally and effectively conducted these negotiations and, in particular, agreed that all citizens of the European Union would be treated equally by the British people. I want to make our compatriots aware that, with the support of the European Union, we will not be discriminated against or discriminated against.  Finally, I would like to tell our British friends that if we had negotiated with any other country and 12 days before the end of the transition period, we would not have known what the outcome was, we would have concluded these negotiations a long time ago. Let this be the best proof of our friendship with The United Kingdom. Madam President, I would like everyone in this House and everyone in front of the screens to wish you a merry christmas and a better new year.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has No treaty is not the end of the world. We do not have a treaty with our two largest trading partners – the United States and China – and yet things are going reasonably well. We are also preparing for such a situation with the United Kingdom: today we will adopt further emergency measures. But that is not what we want. We want a good treaty, but we also do not want a treaty at any price; that is why the European Parliament will monitor very closely. Incidentally, we have a special responsibility. We are the only Parliament that will vote on the Treaty. It is not the parliaments of the 27 Member States – nor some regional parliaments – who are voting on it, nor the British House of Commons, but only the European Parliament.  That is why we will be looking very closely. It is also true that we have set a deadline: Sunday is a shift, otherwise we will not have time for it, and then the negotiations must continue in a different way.  We will therefore look closely at whether it is possible to achieve a level playing field, whether it is possible to secure services – in particular public services – and whether it is possible to establish consumer protection standards, whether it is possible to safeguard workers' rights and further improve the environment. We want to see all this in a treaty. The door is still open. So, Boris, please keep calm and make it happen!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, I am an optimist by nature.  I think that ultimately there will be a deal, because it is in the interest of both parties to have a deal. In the interest of the UK and also in the interest of the European Union, but let’s be a little bit realistic. Everybody talks now about how someday there has to be a deal possible. Hopefully, yes, but let’s be realistic. It could be that we need all the time to negotiate this the deal. Then there could be solutions for that. A technical prolongation of the transition, a provisional application of the agreement, or even stopping the clock! That’s also done in such negotiations. What is now the most important for us all is not to panic from the European side and to fully support our negotiator, Michel Barnier, and to have fair competition in the end. Because it’s about that.  It will be far more devastating for our companies if the outcome of this negotiation is unfair competition to their disadvantage. That is the reason why we have to continue to be very clear on this. There has to be a level playing field: no unfair competition can be accepted.  Also on fish. If they want us to eat their fish, well, we have to have the possibility to catch their fish, in their waters. That’s the bit. One last remark that I want to make, is a request to Michel Barnier, and to the negotiation team, that is to do something on Erasmus. I know the cherry-picking attitude from the Brits, which is in fact devastating for Erasmus, but let’s take a unilateral measure towards the students in Britain that they can continue unilaterally to make use of Erasmus.  It’s a pro-European generation this young generation and it’s this generation which will bring the UK back inside the European family in the next decades.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, why is the EU not attractive enough for Norway and Switzerland to want to join the EU? Why did the old civilised Country, Great Britain, want to leave the EU? Has this ever been considered in the EU? Has the EU looked in the mirror, or is it always the culprit somewhere else? Britain has already agreed sixty trade agreements, but only agreement with the EU seems almost impossible.  The British wanted their immigration policy back, their border controls back, their own legislation back and the fishing waters back and they would like to get rid of the EU Court of Justice. There is nothing wrong with the British wanting to be an independent state.  Boris Johnson should now ensure that the British get the things that the people voted for back, and the EU should stop leading with fear. By this I mean that the EU likes to scare you that if you leave the EU, from this wonderful paradise, you will get hurt. We should stop intimidating each other with the future. Who among us would have guessed three years ago that we are now wrestling with the coronavirus?  What will happen to the EU in the future or to the EU Member States? It seems like time, but one thing is certain: better to be free and poor than a wealthy and a prisoner. I envy the national pride of the British. Hold on to it, it'll help you survive in a tough world.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Madam President, Mr Barnier, I would like to use my time to talk about fishermen. Their situation is more than worrying. I went to meet the Breton and Norman fishermen, who explained to me the risks that Brexit posed to them. In the north, in Boulogne, for example, 80% of people fish in British waters.  If there was no agreement, European ships would no longer be able to access it. This would lead to the movement of many ships, particularly near the coast, into European waters. This high concentration, but also the unilateral setting of quotas, would cause a real ecological disaster. All fishermen would then be threatened, including those who did not even fish in British waters. But a deal won't solve everything. Despite the promises, it is clear that an agreement will come at the cost of a significant reduction in the European quota. In all cases, Member States must give priority to the protection of small-scale fishing. Quota reductions should not be uniform for the entire fleet, as stipulated in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy. States must use economic, social and environmental criteria to distribute fishing permits. No one would understand that a giant industrial super-trawler that freezes its fish for export to the other side of the world continues to fish if, at the same time, the artisanal fishermen, who sustain the economy of our coastlines and take care of the environment, put the key under the door. The priority is therefore twofold: protect the resources of the sea and protect small-scale fishing. One does not go without the other.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, on the eve of real Brexit, perhaps three quick lessons. Firstly, workers in Great Britain who were fed up with social dumping saw no alternative in this European competition union. Social Europe remained a slogan. Secondly, Boris Johnson, who promised them better working conditions and better wages if they gained independence, has been fighting for a year now for the right to worse wages and worse working conditions for British workers. Imagine it! And finally, a lesson for Flanders. In Flanders, SMEs are going to suffer. It may cost us thousands of jobs and the working conditions in the port of Antwerp will come under pressure for the dockworkers.  And yet the Flemish Interest applauded as the hardest for brexit, as the hardest fools we might say. But no, they know what they're doing. Their nationalism, your nationalism, Mr. Annemans, leads to social degradation, to the breakdown of social security and to lower wages. And I'll tell you right away: it won't pass! No way, Mr Annemans, no way!

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we should go back to the beginning here, why the United Kingdom came out of the European Union in the first place. Because they are disappointed in the functioning of this organization and are not the only ones who are disappointed with the functioning of the European Union. In Croatia, when citizens see how money from European funds is spent, they are also in shock and disbelief and are in love with disappointment. Disappointment catches them when they see how tenders for money from European funds are conducted. I will mention, say, one of the many projects, it is a waste disposal project Babina Gora. Inside, in these contests, you have those old methods to accurately write down the size, color or certain properties of something you procure to narrow the pool of eligibles, so that someone there who is predetermined wins that contest. There are other filters that exclude domestic companies. In Croatia, especially in the economy, it is not uncommon for money to be distributed on the principle of the fastest finger and not on the principle of quality. All without any effective control of European funds. Instead of a means of development, funds have become a means of devastation to the environment and society.  If this organisation is not edinged, Brexit will only be the beginning.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. One thing is certain for the European Parliament: there can be no agreement without the consent of the European Parliament, the Chamber of European Citizens. And there will be no agreement from the European Parliament without detailed substantive and legal scrutiny. I would like to thank all those who have contributed to cohesion within the European Union. In fact, the same thing is always at stake: we, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council defend the European Union's community of law and values. We defend the rights of citizens. We ensure fairness in our dealings with each other. And we support the prolongation of the peace process in Ireland. That is the basis of cohesion, and that is the basis of the negotiations. On the other side of the channel, unfortunately, it has become clear that we never know what tactics are being used, what vanity, which raisins, and I often have the impression that arrogance and double-bodied mendacity towards one's own citizens determine one's own strategy. We are predictable and we are ready to negotiate. And we are prepared for every situation, and that is why we are adopting four contingency plans today to prepare for a hard Brexit without a deal: in the areas of freight and passenger transport, air transport, aviation safety and fisheries. But we also need to bear in mind something else: we must learn the lessons of Brexit in the debate on the future of Europe. We need to learn the lessons of Brexit in dealing with each other. We have many Brexit suspects among us – in Hungary, in Poland, in other Member States.
