Anyone who violates the common law and plays with the citizens for party political reasons does not contribute to securing a common future. Leaving does not solve a problem. No promise from Brexiteers can be implemented other than leaving. This is a defeat.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Dear Maroš, let me begin by thanking you and your team, and of course Michel Barnier, our top negotiator, for the style and commitment you have shown. We are not there yet, of course, but congratulations, no congratulations, but thanks are on the table. Ladies and gentlemen, we have set a new deadline in Parliament because it must be clear until we are prepared and able to evaluate this agreement - and let us hope that there will be an agreement, I will continue to press it. Because this Parliament can be very flexible and we can stretch that very far, but it must be clear that we want to evaluate on the basis of texts, and that we want to evaluate on the fundamentals. And we are prepared to work day and night if there is an agreement on Sunday, but the texts must also be available. Two - I think it is important - so far we have been very much one between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and we must stay that way to the last line. And why? Because the stakes are hugely important. It is about more than a deal with the United Kingdom. It is about the essence of the European Union. That is why, of course, this agreement is so difficult, because it is about the essence of what we stand for.  Yes, it is about our social model and the preservation of that social model and the possibility of strengthening it further. Yes, it is about our protection of the environment and the climate and the possibility of preserving and further strengthening it. And that is the commitment of that agreement and no one, ladies and gentlemen, should not threaten that, not even our fine and good friends from the United Kingdom.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: – Madam President, Otto von Habsburg was a Member of the European Parliament for 20 years after 1979. He believed profoundly in the essential unity of the European peoples. He insisted that an empty chair be kept in the Chamber of the European Parliament to symbolise his belief in the inevitable accession of central and Eastern European countries. Madam President, 16 million UK voters voted to remain in the European Union. They were Northern Irish, they were Scots, they were Londoners, but above all they were young people, and I believe we should keep an empty chair in our Chamber to symbolise our hope in their eventual return and the welcome they will receive. I’m not sure if I’ll be here to see that day, but I very much hope that I live to see the day when UK MEPs come back through the doors of our Chamber. And if that chair symbolises nothing else, it should symbolise the towering achievement of the European Union in helping to broker peace on the island of Ireland and bringing about a golden age of Anglo-Irish relations, whether through accession in 1973, the Good Friday Agreement in 1998 and its implementation, and now the Northern Ireland Protocol. I hope and believe that I can say with confidence that Ireland will be the first to welcome them back.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: – Madam President, the EU commenced trade negotiations with excessive demands for ECJ jurisdiction, regulatory alignment on EU terms and maximum EU fishing rights. Britain wanted a Canada-style deal and regulatory sovereignty.  Since then, the EU gave way on the ECJ in return for UK acceptance of the regulatory status quo. Negotiations also shifted from dynamic realignment to rules that would allow Brussels to offset high EU costs, imposed by future EU climate change standards, not applicable in the UK. If such sanctions respect WTO ceilings and leave Britain to trade freely with other countries, UK sovereignty would not be unduly abridged.  Germany has a huge trade surplus with Britain. France gains too. UK trade is vital to Ireland, whilst EU trade matters even more to the British economy. In these circumstances, a trade deal is almost an imperative of reason.  May I therefore remind the EU that trade deals are about trade and mutual advantage and not about climate change or world rescue missions. Nor is it wise to make every issue a point of principle.  Let me close, unusually perhaps, on a positive note. If reason prevails and a deal is struck, this will be due in no small measure to Michel Barnier’s commitment, acumen and diplomatic sensitivity. And as for the charge, he’s bypassing Parliament, that is the very last thing that crossed my mind as a member of the UK Coordination Group.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, and most of all dear friends in the UK, no matter what is going to be in the deal that might or will hopefully shape EU—UK relations in the future, one thing is absolutely clear: the best deal the UK could get – and it will stay that way – was to be part of the European Union, to sit here around the table in Brussels and to take decisions together. No matter what is going to happen in the next days, weeks, months or years ahead, we must always remember our interdependence will always be stronger than Brexit, our ties will always be stronger than Brexit, and our friendship will always be stronger than Brexit.  It is the end of the year and we are close to the end of the transition period. So, friends in the UK, so long for auld lang syne. Ce n’est qu’un au revoir, nos amis; auf Wiedersehen und, hoffentlich, bis ganz bald!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, since June 2016, we’ve been discussing Brexit in a largely similar fashion in this House. We have constantly reiterated our respect for the British people’s decision to leave our Union. We have constantly reiterated that we would like a close and mutually beneficial relationship and we have clearly laid out our negotiating positions in a transparent way. Yes, this has not been a smooth process – anything but, in fact – but then that’s the norm for divorces.  We have witnessed the issue of Brexit dominate the political landscape in the United Kingdom with intense debate and division. And here in the EU, it has never been far from the top of our agenda and has diverted our attention from other key issues. This process has been painstaking and the cause of lingering anxiety. But we’re finally beginning to see light at the end of the tunnel.  I urge you not to fall at the final hurdle. We must hold our nerve, trust our excellent negotiators, led by the remarkable Michel Barnier, and facilitate, in any way we can, the final phase of this process. Yes, even if that is provisional application, although this should only be a last resort. Although we stand on the edge, looking nervously at a no-deal, we must remember that much progress has been made. We’ve a formal agreement on how the new Irish Sea border will operate, which will provide businesses and people on our island with clarity and stability, while upholding the integrity of our single market and the Good Friday Agreement, which Michel Barnier mentioned, and also in relation to the Internal Market Bill, which Commissioner Šefčovič negotiated successfully. We have an agreement on the vast majority of areas, and have even made significant progress on a level playing field, but we have some very difficult areas in relation to fishing outstanding.  However, deal or no-deal, there will be significant economic effects. The Brexit reserve fund (Brexit Adjustment Reserve), therefore, must be allocated under clear and fair criteria so that businesses who are most affected by Brexit are given the support they need in a timely manner. This needs to be a priority in our recovery from COVID-19.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Much water has flowed under the bridges since David Cameron made the fatal decision almost eight years ago to promise a referendum on EU membership, in order to win a national election. What has followed since then has undoubtedly been a tragedy in several acts, but now the drama is finally coming to an end.  The only constant that has been positive in all these long years of negotiations has been our ability, within europe, to stay together, and our ability to stay calm. It is important that we have the strength to hold this all the way to the finish line and not to compromise on the principles that have carried us through the negotiations. We must have an agreement that ensures high social and environmental standards. We must continue to have good transport links between the EU and the UK. However, this must be done in a way that does not jeopardise the working conditions of all those working in the transport sector in Europe.  I am pleased that we are going to adopt transitional arrangements here today to ensure basic air links and road freight between the EU and the UK. But this can in no way replace an agreement between the EU and the UK. Finally, to our chief negotiator, to the Commission: hold on, hold on, stick to our principles. We will stand behind you.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Brexit is a fact to which we must relate. There are no winners, really just losers. However, the need for cooperation to get us out of the climate crisis and overcome the pandemic has never been greater. The momentum for rules-based trade and cooperation on equal terms remains equally high. The desire of all of us to travel, study, live and live, between our countries continues. We are not the ones who voted britain out. It is Britain that leaves the EU, but not Europe. Now we need and expect an agreement on the rules of the game, for cooperation and for a common future.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: – Madam President, first of all I want to thank Michel Barnier and all the negotiators for their endless effort. Nevertheless we in a very uncomfortable situation. We have two weeks before the deadline and no one knows what will happen. Yes, it is good that we are still negotiating, and it is good that we could prevent a no deal so far, but the situation we are in is really unacceptable. Business and citizens do not know what will happen, and the European Parliament itself finds in a very difficult dilemma – either, if there is a deal we are creating huge chaos on 1 January, or we just give up our scrutiny rights.  It is absolutely clear a deal with a strong level playing field is still the best outcome for everyone, but we at the European Parliament cannot make a fool of ourselves and just let go out of hand our scrutiny riots. We are not just a rubber stamp institution and we need proper time. For me the time until 28 December is far too short, and I think we should push for technical prolongation in order to have proper time for scrutiny.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, a big European economy is voluntarily leaving a preferential economic and trade area and the world’s biggest and most influential standard—setting and regulatory power. Last Sunday, another negotiation deadline passed with no final outcome, and what we have just heard from Michel Barnier is that on the negotiation table at least one big, and a number of little pieces, remain without solution.  We continue to be in the No Deal territory and failure is still possible. We must be also aware that even if a skinny agreement is better than no-deal, it will bring a higher level of distortions than a more ambitious deal, and even the most effective preparatory measures will not protect us fully from distortions.  The good news here is the agreement reached on the full and timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and my appreciation goes to Maroš Šefčovič and his team, but we still have to understand better how, and to what extent, it is warranted that there are no risks there. I support the Commission’s attempts to keep negotiations alive as long as there is a chance for agreement. No Deal has never been our option, especially in the midst of the current crisis, but negotiating under tremendous time pressure cannot lead to an agreement at any cost. I also expect from the British Government that the sovereignty argument will not become a pretext for a No Deal calamity.  As most of us here, I am concerned about the ongoing process. So far, we have stayed calm and carried on, but the proposed new deadline stretches beyond what normally we would be ready to accept. We will be deprived of our basic rights relating to international agreements. Paradoxically, the pandemic has helped us organise a last—minute remote plenary meeting, but evidently there is no time for any responsible scrutiny of the text.  So let me finish by saying that in opening ourselves at the cost of our democratic prerogatives to this unprecedented flexibility, Parliament shows its willingness to pay this price, because achieving agreement on a future partnership will allow us to keep liaising over the Channel in the long term, and this is a price worth paying.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for the work, the good work done by Mr Barnier and his entire team. I think you've done the best work you could do, but, ladies and gentlemen, we didn't have it easy.  This is a negotiation , we have been - with a president who came to British Prime Minister for his toughness in the face of the Brexit negotiations. So, it wasn't going to be easy, it wasn't going to make it easy for us. Still, I want an agreement to be reached, even if there are only twelve days left.  But I want, above all, to bring the voice of farmers and companies that are going to be affected, of many people who have great uncertainty. But especially, as a fisheries spokesperson for my group, that of this fisheries sector: those more than three thousand vessels, one and a half million people directly affected by the lack of agreement. With that uncertainty, what's going to happen on January 1st?  And what I want to say and ask the Commission is that we do everything we can to reach an agreement, but let us not forget this sector and do not leave it behind, because we know that for the British it is a symbol of Brexit hard to regain sovereignty of the waters. The fishing sector has to feel the encouragement of this House, and I ask everyone.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Vice-President Šefčovič and Mr Barnier for their continued efforts. The UK will remain an important partner and friend of the EU. Therefore the ultimate goal should always be a comprehensive agreement, reflecting our close relationship. But, the new free trade agreement must be based on reciprocity and a fair system of rules. As we head towards the last and very real Brexit deadline, I cannot overstate the growing frustration in the EU. We are dealing with a lot of uncertainty caused by pressure from a strict deadline that the UK set itself. As I can see in the Netherlands, exporters are already facing long queues at Calais to cross the Channel, and as MEPs we need to be able to explain to our citizens and businesses what they can expect from 1 January. Therefore we need sufficient time for scrutiny in case of a deal. This is part of our responsibility toward citizens and businesses who need clarity.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, I am confident that the negotiators will reach an ambitious agreement as soon as possible, in line with the many historical, political, human and economic ties between the United Kingdom and the European Union. But today I would like to refer mainly to the question of fishing.  As you will recall, both sides undertook, in the 2019 political declaration, to ratify a fisheries agreement by 1 June this year. It is a sad paradox that, thirteen days after the end of the transition period, we not only do not have a fisheries agreement, but that fishing remains the main stumbling block of the negotiations.  Mr Barnier knows that he has the full support of this house to reach an agreement that guarantees the rights of European fishermen. We need ambition, stability and predictability: there are many jobs and investments at stake; there are many years our fishermen have been fishing in British waters. On the other hand, there are many tonnes of fish and seafood that, exported from the UK, arrive daily in European markets.  Both the Commission and the Council know that the European Parliament has always given particular relevance to the connection of access to water and resources with market access. Finally, we cannot let the European fisheries sector down: it needs a stable agreement.  In any case — whether there is agreement or not — the European Union must be prepared for any eventuality, as evidenced by the contingency measures we are voting on today.  In addition, I would urge the Commission to intensify its efforts to implement the Brexit adjustment reserve as soon as possible. This five billion euro fund should pay particular attention to the support of the fisheries sector and coastal communities, including the first fishing region in Europe, which is Galicia.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, I think we’re facing two basic problems: one is to reach an agreement before the end of the transition period, while the other is to allow sufficient time for parliamentary scrutiny. This second point is very important because I’m afraid that – at least according to the public information we have in the media – this seems to have been an afterthought for our negotiators, because it is never mentioned that we need to get this agreement before the end of the year but also to allow sufficient time for parliamentary scrutiny. So, I think this should now be made a clear part of this last step of the negotiations. If there is not sufficient time for an agreement before the end of the year with sufficient parliamentary scrutiny, we have to make sure there is no chaos on 1 January, and we have to make part of the negotiations agreeing to maintain the status quo on both sides of the Channel while we complete the negotiations and parliamentary scrutiny.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, today we mark the end of a Chapter. Four and a half years after the Brexit vote blindness has finally triumphed. Even before the divorce is complete, we can see the looming catastrophe. Lorries queue for 24 hours in Dover. Tourists will lose insurance. Delays and passport stamps on Eurostar. Dear British friends, is this what you voted for? Passport stamps and lorry queues? This moment is a victory for Europe. There can be no clearer vindication of the European project. The farce that it is a European nation, alone outside of the EU, is being exposed.  To my British friends I say, politics may change but geography will not change. The future shall only be less kind to a small island on the periphery of the world’s largest trading bloc. I’m afraid you’ll soon discover that you’re neither having your cake nor eating it. And when you inevitably come back, there will be no pound, no preferential treatment. These are the consequences of the choices you made. Until then, good luck.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support No one would have thought that a week before Christmas we still do not know on what conditions the UK will leave the EU's internal market on 1 January. The British voted to leave in 2016. This decision must be respected. There is no room for vengeance and unfulmountable demands. I hope that the Commission will negotiate in this spirit. At the same time, the other party must acknowledge that withdrawal involves not only entitlements, but also obligations. And a divorce is always difficult for both parties. Due to future good neighbourly relations, it is important to reach an agreement that benefits both the Union and the island country. To do this, we must remain pragmatic and remain realistic, and as soon as an agreement is reached, Parliament, the Council, the Member States must do everything possible to put it into effect as soon as possible. Whether there is a deal or not, disruptions to freight traffic and transport are guaranteed from 1 January. I ask the Commission to do everything possible to inform EU companies so that they can prepare as much as possible. I call on the Member States and the United Kingdom to facilitate the transition so that there is as little damage as possible to citizens and companies. The main goal is to reduce chaos. The two losers, since with the withdrawal, I am convinced that both the island nation and the Union will lose, it would be good to find each other again as partners.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, we will not end this parliamentary year with a very nice debate, although ... If we manage to make a deal on Wednesday, we will come back after Christmas to sign that deal as well. But reaching the deal turns out to be anything but easy and it also puts a lot of pressure on us-uk relations. It is clear to me that we must have a level playing field between the EU and the UK after Brexit. This must be ensured and we must maintain decent working conditions and working conditions, even after Brexit. Brexit must not lead to a deregulation of the UK labour market. Because fair is fair: zero-hours contracts, insecure contracts are already the standard in the UK, and I don't believe Prime Minister Johnson intends to make this better, but rather worse... If the UK wants to maintain access to the European market, we must demand that it treat its workers decently, also in the interests of European and Dutch workers.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, as far as I am concerned, Brexit is a very stupid decision, but we cannot control the behaviour of Prime Minister Johnson and his government. What we do have in hand is our response. We must be aware, ladies and gentlemen, that our single market is worth EUR 14 million, the British barely EUR 2 million. We have 446 million consumers, they are 66 million. These are the facts, and no limp narrative about national sovereignty or flag-waving can be countered. We do not give up the level playing field for that, ladies and gentlemen. We are not going to embarrass our own European companies. In these negotiations, we must rely on our own strength and ensure a strong agreement for our companies, before our fishermen, for the students. Mr President, I think I am speaking on behalf of the whole of Parliament when I say that we are united in support of Michel Barnier because we know that our strength lies in our unity. L'union fait la force. I say it in French but I think they will understand that in Britain as well.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When I stand here today, with exactly two weeks to go until Britain's first day outside the European Union, we still do not have an agreement, which I regret, of course. Britain is both an important neighbour and a trading partner, and we need to have as close a relationship as possible.  I am worried about what a hard Brexit would mean, not least for small businesses that are the backbone of Europe's economy. We know that they are not sufficiently prepared for the chaotic situation that is looming. It is easy for politicians to say: prepare! But it's very hard to do that when you don't know what.  Large companies are more experienced in trading with third countries, but it is, of course, much more difficult for the smaller ones. Now the Commission must do all it can to facilitate, not least for small businesses, so that trade flows and other things between the EU and the UK can be maintained. The European Parliament presented our recommendations in a resolution last summer. In this, we stressed that the Commission must take extra account of small businesses, including by setting up contact points for SMEs and also facilitating the bureaucratic process so that the administrative burden is as small as possible. Since we have heard nothing about this being a problem in the negotiations, I hope and assume that we have achieved these things in the negotiations. If that is not the case, it would be nice to know.  I would like to conclude by wishing the President, the Commissioner, Mr Barnier and all my colleagues a really, really merry Christmas. I hope that we will see each other again in the intervening days in order to examine a negotiated agreement.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, as we reach the end of this turbulent year with last-minute negotiations, I welcome yesterday’s conclusions on the Withdrawal Agreement, notably guaranteeing the rights of the EU and the UK citizens. It is vital to preserve the rights of citizens currently in the European Union and the UK, but I regret that the highest price will be paid by future citizens.  The UK has been a member of the European Union for 47 years, helping with the development of our Union despite conflicting positions on some issues. However, time is running out and we as a European Union need to preserve our values, commitments and our integrity. I expect the UK side to respect this as well. Finally, allow me to stress the role of the European Parliament and the need for scrutiny, bearing in mind our tremendous patience so far. However, only mutual trust can build sustainable bridges for our future cooperation in the ever-challenging future.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, firstly I’m an optimist, so I still hope that there can be a deal and I believe there should be a deal. Bear in mind, if we fail to reach an agreement between the European Union and the UK, it would have been a failure of politics and diplomacy. But equally, it will have failed livelihoods across the European Union - coastal communities in Ireland, France and Spain, people working in factories in Germany and people whose livelihoods will be impacted in the UK as well. So, for all our sakes, I urge everybody involved to ensure that there’s goodwill in these last few hours of negotiations to protect the livelihoods of European citizens.  I also want to put on the record my great appreciation to the Commission and to Michel Barnier, who is a household name in Ireland at this stage, for the support and effort that he put into ensuring that the Northern Ireland Protocol and the challenging issues and unique circumstances on the island of Ireland were very much addressed. And I thank the European Union and this Parliament for the solidarity with the Irish people as well, in the context of Brexit negotiations.  So, we have just but hours. But these hours are crucial because they could set in train years of dissent between the UK and the European Union if we cannot come to an agreement in everybody’s interest.  I wish you well and I wish the people of Europe a Happy Christmas and a peaceful New Year.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, here we are in the final stretch of this negotiation. Only ten days before the deadline, more than a few useful hours. At such a critical moment, having followed our debates, I do not understand that some are still clinging here to theoretical discussions and seeking to repeat the Brexit match, would like the failure of the negotiations to serve as a lesson to either the British or the European Union, or to try to discuss the place of our assembly in the games of apparatus. It seems to me that only one thing should count in this crucial moment: to seek the interests of the citizens of our countries to the end. For them, as for all of us, as for our British friends, we must give a full chance to an agreement until the end. This will be crucial for the geopolitical balance of the world of tomorrow and essential for the protection of our economies, which are already so distressed by the current crisis and which, in fact, would be further weakened by a breakdown in our industrial and trade ties and by a brake imposed on the entire agricultural sector.  And how can we not call him back? This would of course be a dramatic situation for the fishing sector in our countries, as, for that matter, a real problem for British fishermen deprived of their opportunities. There are jobs at stake, from Boulogne-sur-Mer to Lorient, from Zeebruges to Rotterdam. There are territories whose dynamism is based on the vitality of this activity and its historical link with the sharing of our waters. There are lives at stake and, in the days to come, that alone must count. Thanks to our negotiating team, fishing has never been an adjustment variable in this discussion. It must remain a priority until the last minute and we know we can count on Michel Barnier for that. The uncertainty we are in must finally force us to prepare for all eventualities. We agreed to validate contingency measures in fast-track procedure: it was necessary to be able to ensure that a rupture without agreement was accompanied. But we cannot wait until we are at the foot of the wall for the Commission to be concerned about the solutions to the major crisis that this would produce and, Commissioner, we must move quickly on this point, with a double demand for efficiency and transparency. We are ready to work continuously until 1 January to have concrete solutions for all those who will be directly impacted and who will be the first to be affected by a Brexit without a deal.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, of course we are voting on these emergency measures for fisheries and transport. That said, for fishing, it is without really expecting anything from these measures, because if they are better than nothing, they do not solve anything. And if unfortunately they were activated, they would put us in a situation where the United Kingdom would decide almost on a case-by-case basis who is going to fish in its waters and what, with no visibility for European fishermen. And that is precisely what we must avoid: a permanent negotiating situation. A situation where an entire industrial sector would be deprived of the visibility essential to its life, to its survival. We have just experienced it for the last three years, and investments have not been made in this sector, the fishing sector, which needs it. Holding the position of a sustainable, balanced and long-term agreement: this is what Michel Barnier has carried. Tomorrow, a new page will open. We will have to hold that position over and over again. In the event of a non-agreement, these emergency measures will not have to last forever, and that is why they have an end. Whatever happens, we cannot put ourselves in a situation where what is valid one day would be called into question overnight, at the whim of our British friends. Let's restore visibility to this sector.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, first I really would like to thank you for your continuous support and close cooperation. Michel Barnier, myself and our teams always appreciated your availability, your interest and also your detailed knowledge of the subject. I fully understand the concerns, the points raised by honourable MEPs, Mr McAllister, Ms García Pérez, Mr Hansen, Ms Hübner, about the importance to maintain this level of transparency as high as possible until the last moments.  You know very well that the Commission published its draft agreement and all additional text and documents submitted to the UK in the course of negotiations. As you know, both Michel and myself, but also our teams, have always been ready to brief you in all details. We know that only through the utmost transparency and dialogue we can earn your trust, we can earn your support and I also know that it was thanks to this trust and support that we built this unbreakable European unity which was so important and is still is very important in these negotiations. I would just plead to do the same which we did in this marathon negotiation. Let’s work together and let’s walk this last most difficult mile in this united approach, being fully aware of our priorities and I would like to reassure Mr Lamberts and Mr Lange that your support is absolutely crucial. You consent is decisive. The consent of this House is a key to ratification of the deal, and therefore, I also want to thank you for your support in these exceptional, demanding and difficult – for all of us – circumstances. Many of the honourable Members raised the issue of full respect for social, environmental and labour standards. Almost all those who intervened highlighted the importance of fair competition. Mr Scholz, Ms Loiseau, and many others, I really would like to assure you that we will deliver on all of these priorities, because I fully understand how important it is for the European Union, how important it is for the citizens you represent in this House.  I was listening very carefully to Mr Sikorski and Mr Silva Pereira about the concerns they have on the issue of the rights of the EU citizens, and I want to assure all of you that there’s almost five million people, EU and UK citizens, who are most directly affected by Brexit because of the residence rights, that they will be fully protected. I would say the rights of citizens and full implementation of the Ireland and Northern Ireland protocol being the most important issues which we’ve been negotiating day and night with our UK partners under the withdrawal agreement, and I’m glad to say that on this we have absolute full consensus. Mr Warborn, Mr Kelly and Mr Schirdewan have been highlighting the issue of SMEs, of fisheries and other sectors which might be severely affected by Brexit and, therefore, I’m glad to say that the Brexit adjustment reserve is being finalised as a part of the next multiannual finance perspective. I hope and believe that some of the five billion euros which are aimed at countering the possible adverse consequences in the Member States will be able to compensate the sectors which have been affected the most by the departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union.  As you know very well, Europe never leaves their people and their businesses behind, to be fair, to be socially just, this core European value, and I am absolutely sure that we will demonstrate it in this case as well. I also understand the calls of many of you to remind us of the importance of the EU—UK relationship, of the EU—UK friendship between our peoples and I would say that it is exactly because of this that we are engaged in this most comprehensive agreement, to be negotiated in the shortest time in the European Union’s history. If you allow me, I would like to conclude with repeating the words of Ursula von der Leyen and Michel Barnier, that this is now the moment of truth. There is a narrow path to agreement. Our negotiators are currently, now, right at this moment, exploring every possible way how to walk this difficult last mile and how to push the negotiations over the finishing line with positive results. So let us wish them well. Let us wish success in the endeavour so that we can conclude this very difficult chapter and open a new one in our EU—UK relationship. Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this very important and lively debate and I also would like to wish all of you a Merry Christmas and a peaceful New Year.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The situation of the negotiations between the European Union and the United Kingdom on a future trade agreement is worrying. The latest signals received indicate significant bottlenecks that risk affecting the approval of this agreement so necessary for both sides. Unfortunately, the lack of transparency on the negotiations is raising questions and does not allow the European Parliament and citizens to analyse in detail the elements discussed and to be able to support the negotiations for their swift approval by the European legislature. More worrying is the fact that EU Member States are not sufficiently prepared for the assumption of a no-deal scenario. The business environment, university cooperation or European citizens are at risk of serious harm. The right-wing government in Romania has done nothing to prepare for this hypothesis. There is no legal regulation adopted, no financial support package for companies affected by the situation, no citizen support crisis cell, absolutely nothing that the EU has recommended. I call on negotiators and decision-makers on both sides to become more involved in resolving this situation. No one can afford a failure but at the same time, no one can afford a bad deal. The solution is in our hands, in the will and ability to advance and to have this trade agreement.

name: László TRÓCSÁNYI
text: Writing. – With regard to the WITHDRAWAL of the United Kingdom, it is important to note that one of the main objectives should be to ensure a transition with as few problems as possible, especially in areas of judicial cooperation and other areas of a legal nature. Cooperation between the two countries covers civil law, family law, commercial law and criminal law. There are a significant number of Hungarian communities in Britain, so this has an impact on trade, justice and other relations. We're connected on a number of threads. It would create a more reassuring situation for both parties if the agreement in question adequately covered cooperation in criminal and civil judicial matters. It is important that judicial cooperation in security, law enforcement and criminal matters, as well as judicial cooperation in civil and family law matters, form an integral part of the agreement, and it is in the best interests of both parties to guarantee legal certainty to citizens. Good judicial relations and mutual trust are in the interests of both parties. Furthermore, allow me to stress that Michel Barnier has successfully represented the interests of the European Union and its citizens during the withdrawal process and is being hailed for his work.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Now for the second round of today's votes. We will vote on the documents on the agenda. The vote will take place from 13.30 to 14.45. The voting method is the same as in previous voting rounds. All votes will be roll call votes. I hereby open the second round of voting. they have until 2.45pm to vote. The results of the second round of voting will be announced at 17.00. (The sitting was suspended at 1.30 p.m.)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we shall now proceed to the results of today's second round of voting. Final vote, second round of voting: Deterioration of the human rights situation in Egypt, joint motion for a resolution adopted. Report by Mr Beazley on beazley: Pierre Larrouturou, Mr Olivier Chastel on the new general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021, approved. The Council's position of 14 December 2020 was approved by Parliament without amendment. Under Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the budgetary procedure for the financial year 2021 can therefore be considered to have been completed.  I therefore declare the European Union budget for the financial year 2021 finally adopted.  I invite the two rapporteurs to join me in the budget signing ceremony. (The President signed the budget) Let us now resume with the results of the votes on the four emergency measures that will be implemented in the event of no agreement with the United Kingdom. Common rules on basic links for the carriage of goods and passengers by road at the end of the transition period in relation to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union, Commission proposal, approved. Common rules on air transport connectivity at the end of the transition period in relation to the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the Union, approved. Air safety at the end of the transition period in relation to the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union, approved. Fishing authorisations for Union vessels in United Kingdom waters and fishing operations of United Kingdom vessels in Union waters, approved. Before declaring the session of the European Parliament adjourned, I would like to extend merry Christmas and happy holidays to all my fellow Members and, of course, to their families and loved ones.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
